\title{Expectation Formation and Risk-Taking under Uncertainty: Evidence from Car Race
Experiments} 

\author{ Markus Schaffner \\ Gigi Foster, Paul Frijters, Benno Torgler}


% \addtobeamertemplate{title page}{}{\center{}

% \institute[]
% {
% School of Economics and Finance\\
% Queensland University of Technology
% }

% \date{November 18, 2008}

\subject{OET}


% \pgfdeclareimage[height=0.5cm,width=0.5cm]{university-logo}{QUT_LogoSquare_RGB}
% \logo{\pgfuseimage{university-logo}}

\newcommand\source{\onslide<1->\small\emph}

\begin{document}

\section{Introduction and Motivation}

\begin{frame}
\titlepage
\end{frame}



\begin{frame}
\frametitle{The BIG picture.}
%\framesubtitle{}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Expectations in economics are often analysed in a \alert<1>{static}
  manner:
  \item $u_{t-1} = E[u_t]$
  \pause 
  \item \alert{Dynamics}  of the process are under explored:
  \item $\int_{t-1}^t u = x?$
  \item $\Longrightarrow$ This project aims to change this.
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
\frametitle{The first step.}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Explore the \alert{statics of expectation formation}.
  \item Understanding how people form expectations about the outcome of an
  uncertain process, and how this relates to their actual choice.
  \item Observe the link between expectations, decisions and individuals' values
  and beliefs.
  \item Run experiment with which will allow to examine the
  dynamic part as well.
  \item Establish \alert{how expectation are formed} and
  what are important covariates.
\end{itemize}
\end{frame}


\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Expectation formation.}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Depending on the situation and \alert{coping mechanism} people might be
  over- or underestimating the outcome of a uncertain event.
  \item There might also be an individual effect which changes how people
  approach the issue.
  \item \ldots (more from the background lit here if appropriate).
\end{itemize}
\end{frame}


\section{Experimental design}

\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Experimental design issues.}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Confront participants with a \alert<1>{noisy random outcome} that
  evolves over a \alert<1>{time frame}.
  \pause
  \item Make participants \alert<2>{care about the ``monetary'' outcome}.
  \pause
  \item Establish \alert<3>{emotional ownership on the outcome}.
  \pause
  \item Get \alert<4>{expectations AND behavioural evidence} at several points
  during the unfolding of the event.
  \pause
  \item Obtain a number of \alert<5>{psychological and socio-economic
  covariates}.
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}


\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Modeling of the random outcome.}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Six \alert{animated car races} for 10 laps with 5 cars.
  \item Cars race all with the same AR(1)-like random process.
  \item Cars are prone to \alert{engine failures} which will set them back (4 failures
  in 10 laps on average).
  \item There are \alert{three pitstops} at laps 3, 6, and 9 where participants can drop
  out.
  \item The race is designed to be interesting and to feel ``real''.
  
\end{itemize}

% \begin{equation}
% s_{t} = \theta * s_{base} + ((1-\theta) * s_{t-dt} * (1 + (\gamma * U()* - (\gamma / 2))))
%  \end{equation}

\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
\frametitle{How to make participant care about the outcome?}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Participants had to earn their income in a \alert{real effort task}
  (solving cross sum problems over 5 minutes).
  \item The betting process involves a \alert{tradeoff between the amount to bet 
  and the failure rate of their car}.
  \pause
  \item $\Longrightarrow$ \textbf{Mechanics:}
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Betting of 100\% will reduce chances of winning close to zero.
    \item Betting of 50\% will give a chance of 1 in 5 of winning the race
    (equal failrate as the other cars).
    \item Betting of 0\% will increase chances of winning to almost certainty
    (but nothing to gain).
  \end{itemize}
  \item Winning the race yields a payoff of 5-15 times the betting amount
  (depending on the treatment). $\Longrightarrow$ Very steep payoff function.
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}



\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Emotional involvement}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Attachment to the earned income through real effort task.
  \item Choose the \alert{colour} of the car from 4 options (blue, magenta,
  red, yellow) in each race. 
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}


\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Pre race investment screen}

\begin{figure}[ht!]
  \centering 
  \includegraphics[width=80mm]{screen01.png}
  \label{pict:sinvest}
  \caption{Screenshot of the pre-race investment screen with sliders to choose
  the amount to bet and to enter the expectations about the 
  outcome of the race.}
\end{figure}

\framezoom<1><2>(2.3cm,1.3cm)(6.8cm,2.5cm)

\end{frame}



\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Expectation elicitation}

\begin{itemize}
  \item \alert{Before each race} on the investment screen.
  \item At \alert{each pitstop} at three points during the race.
  \item Two questions:

\begin{itemize}
  \item \emph{Out of a 1000 races, how often do you think your car would
  arrive first?}
  \item \emph{How confident are you that your guess is roughly right?}
\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}

\end{frame}


\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Collecting behavioural evidence}

\begin{itemize}
  \item At the pitstops, participants can drop out for 40\%, 25\%, 10\% of the
  betting amount.
\end{itemize}

\begin{figure}[ht!] 
  \centering 
  \includegraphics[width=65mm]{screen02.png}
  \label{pict:pitstop}
  \caption{Screenshot of the car race at the first pitstop showing the
  positions of the cars and  the payoffs for the respective events.}
\end{figure}

\framezoom<1><2>(3.0cm,3.4cm)(6.0cm,2.0cm)

\end{frame}


\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Psychological scales and socio-economic variables}

\begin{itemize}
  \item A number of psychological and economic scales at the beginning of the
  experiment.
  \item Question sets on: \alert{Self esteem}, \alert{Optimism},
  \alert{Savouring}, \alert{Locus of Control}, and \alert{Risk Aversion} 
  \item Additional demographics questionaire at the end of the experiment.
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}



\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Stages of the experiment}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Introductory questionnaire
  \item Relaxation: 5 min of beach sounds (voiceover introduction)
  \item Real effort task (cross-sum calculations) leading to income earning
  \item Test race: 3 laps with voiceover
  \item 6 real races
  \item 6 rounds of `Guess the Winner'
  \item Demographics questionnaire
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}



\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Treatments}

\begin{table}
\begin{tabular}{lp{3cm}c}
\textbf{Treatment} & \textbf{Win-Value} & \textbf{Show-Up Fee} \\  \hline
Baseline & 5 times the bet & \$ 5 \\
Low Stakes & \textbf{2 times} the bet, \emph{but payoff for 2nd and 3rd place}
& \$ 5 \\ High Stakes & \textbf{15 times} the bet & \$ 5 \\
Wealth & 5 times the bet & \textbf{\$ 20}
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

\end{frame}



\section{Analysis and regressions}

\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Analysis I: Stated expectation vs. real winning percentage}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Examine relationship between:
  \item \alert{Subjective winning percentage} as stated by the participant on the
  pitstop. (EXPECTATION)
  \item \alert{Real winning percentage} as obtained by running simulations of the races
  from the pitstop position. (WINPC)
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}


\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Analysis I: EXPECTATION vs. WINPC}
\framesubtitle{Scatterplot}

\begin{figure}[ht!]
  \centering 
  \includegraphics[width=80mm]{scatterexp1.png}
  \label{pict:scatter1}
  \caption{Scatterplot of expected vs. real winning chance at the pitstop.}
\end{figure}

\end{frame}


\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Analysis I: EXPECTATION vs. WINPC}
\framesubtitle{Kernel plot}

\begin{figure}[ht!]
  \centering 
  \includegraphics[width=80mm]{kernel1.png}
  \label{pict:kern1}
  \caption{Kernel plot, with 45 degree line for reference}
\end{figure}

\end{frame}


\begin{frame}[shrink=40]
\frametitle{Analysis I: EXPECTATION vs. WINPC}
\framesubtitle{Regression table}

\input{table1.tex}

\end{frame}




\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Analysis I: EXPECTATION vs. WINPC}
\framesubtitle{Discussion}

\begin{itemize}
  \item \emph{WINPC} alone explains about \alert{30\% of the variance}.
  \item Participants are \alert{slightly overconfident} on average.
  \item Treatment difference and progression \alert{do not} significantly change this.
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}


\begin{frame}[shrink=50]
\frametitle{Analysis II: Determinants of expectation formation}
\framesubtitle{Regression table}

\input{table2.tex}

\end{frame}



\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Analysis II: Determinants of expectation formation}
\framesubtitle{Discussion}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Socio-economic factors and psychological scales explain additional 10\%
  of variation.
  \item Key variables
  \begin{itemize}
    \item \textbf{SBI} Savouring index, higher = more savouring person
    \item \textbf{Locus of control} index, higher = more control 
    \item \textbf{Good luck charm} item, higher = belives in them (superstition)
  \end{itemize}
  \item Added individual fixed effects explain up to 70\% of variance.
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}


\begin{frame}[shrink=30]
\frametitle{Analysis III: Behavioural Evidence - OLS}
\framesubtitle{Regression table}

\input{table3.tex}

\end{frame}


\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Analysis III: Behavioural Evidence - OLS}
\framesubtitle{Discussion}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Drop out is affected by stated expectation on top of WINPC.
  \item Effect is small, but robust.
  \item Socio-demographics and psychological scales do not explain much.
  \item Stated risk-aversion has a small positive effect.
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}


\section{Robustness}

\begin{frame}[shrink=30]
\frametitle{Robustness: Behavioural Evidence - probit}
\framesubtitle{Regression table}

\input{table4.tex}

\end{frame}

\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Robustness: Behavioural Evidence - probit}
\framesubtitle{Discussion}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Marginal effects small, but present.
  \item \ldots 
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}



\begin{frame}[containsverbatim,shrink=30]
\frametitle{Robustness: Evidence for emotional involvement}
\framesubtitle{Do participants switch car color after bad outcomes?}

\begin{verbatim}

. probit colswitch Lwin if pitstopnum == 1

Iteration 0:   log likelihood = -757.90149
Iteration 1:   log likelihood = -713.62144
Iteration 2:   log likelihood = -713.45417
Iteration 3:   log likelihood = -713.45416

Probit regression                                 Number of obs   =       1194
                                                  LR chi2(1)      =      88.89
                                                  Prob > chi2     =     0.0000
Log likelihood = -713.45416                       Pseudo R2       =     0.0586

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   colswitch |      Coef.   Std. Err.      z    P>|z|     [95% Conf. Interval]
-------------+----------------------------------------------------------------
        Lwin |  -.8733255   .0945348    -9.24   0.000     -1.05861   -.6880407
       _cons |  -.0862557   .0528079    -1.63   0.102    -.1897573    .0172458
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

. mfx

Marginal effects after probit
      y  = Pr(colswitch) (predict)
         =  .31943427
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
variable |      dy/dx    Std. Err.     z    P>|z|  [    95% C.I.   ]      X
---------+--------------------------------------------------------------------
    Lwin |  -.3120793      .03347   -9.32   0.000  -.377689  -.24647   .438583
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

\end{verbatim}

\end{frame}


\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Robustness: Dynamics}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Do we see evidence of learning and/or confusion?
  \item Findings remain relatively stable over the six races.
  \item Expectation remains stable over the three pitstops.
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}

\frametitle{SD distance of EXPECTATION from WINPC}

\begin{figure}[ht!]

\end{frame}

\end{figure}

\end{frame}

\frametitle{SD difference of EXPECTATION from WINPC over pitstops}

\begin{figure}[ht!]
  \centering

  \caption{Box plot over pitstop number.}
\end{figure}

\end{frame}



\section{Conclusions}


\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Conclusion}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Experiment to observe expectation formation.
  \item Large variance in process $\Longrightarrow$ larger variance in
  responces.
  \item Evidence for rational and emotional responses.
  \item Psychological determinants explain substantial variance of expectation.
  \item We find behavioural evidence for the relevance of expectation.
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}



\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Outlook}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Refine analysis, more robustness tests.
  \item Run additional treatments to explore findings further.
  \item \ldots
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}



\begin{frame}

\begin{columns}
\begin{column}{0.5\textwidth}

\end{column}
\begin{column}{0.5\textwidth}

\Huge{Thank you for your attention}

\end{column}
\end{columns}

\end{frame}

\section{Descriptives}

\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Key Variables}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Expectations as stated at the pitstops (psexpectation).
  \item Real winning percentage from simulations (winpc).
  \item SD of this winning percentage (sdwin).
  \item SD difference between psexpectation and winpc.
  \item Socio-demographics.
  \item Psychological scales.
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}



\begin{frame}[containsverbatim,shrink=30]
\frametitle{psexpectation(\_r)}

Expectation that the participant reports during pitstops about the likelihood of
his car winning the race (reported out of a 1000, rescaled to out of 10 (\_r)).

\begin{verbatim}

. sum psexpectation*

    Variable |       Obs        Mean    Std. Dev.       Min        Max
-------------+--------------------------------------------------------
psexpectat~n |      4299    520.6767    313.1772          0       1000
psexpectat~r |      4299    5.206767    3.131772          0         10
\end{verbatim}


\end{frame}



\begin{frame}[containsverbatim,shrink=30]
\frametitle{winpc(\_r), sdwin}

Actual winning percentage as per simulation of car races and standard deviation
thereof.

\begin{verbatim}

. sum winpc* sdwin

    Variable |       Obs        Mean    Std. Dev.       Min        Max
-------------+--------------------------------------------------------
       winpc |      4299    .4333554    .3496625          0          1
     winpc_r |      4299    4.333554    3.496625          0         10
       sdwin |      4299    .0299721    .0184003          0     .06915

\end{verbatim}

\end{frame}



\begin{frame}[containsverbatim,shrink=30]
\frametitle{gender,age,height,weight,BMI}

Self-reported demographics, weight has some anomalies which hint at misreporting 

\begin{verbatim}

. sum gender age height weight BMI if racenum == 1 & pitstopnum == 1

    Variable |       Obs        Mean    Std. Dev.       Min        Max
-------------+--------------------------------------------------------
      gender |       237    .5485232    .4986931          0          1
         age |       237    22.08861    3.688702         11         47
      height |       236    168.7373    9.839502        140        195
      weight |       235    64.65191    16.98907         30        162
         BMI |       235    22.63722    5.328155   11.71875   61.72839

\end{verbatim}


\begin{figure}[ht!]
  \centering 
  \includegraphics[width=60mm]{weight.png}
  \label{pict:histweight}
  \caption{}
\end{figure}

\end{frame}




\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Analysis of stated expectation}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Edge effects? Restrict sample to non-border cases (winpc 10\% -
  90 \%)
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}



\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Expected vs. real winning chance}

\begin{figure}[ht!]
  \centering 
  \includegraphics[width=80mm]{scatterexp2.png}
  \label{pict:scatter2}
  \caption{Scatterplot of expected vs. real winning chance per pitstop with
  restricted sample }
\end{figure}

\end{frame}


\begin{frame}
\frametitle{Expected vs. real}

\begin{figure}[ht!]
  \centering 
  \includegraphics[width=80mm]{kernel2.png}
  \label{pict:kern2}
  \caption{Kernel plot, with 45 degree line for reference with restricted
  sample}
\end{figure}

\end{frame}



\begin{frame}[shrink=30,containsverbatim]
\frametitle{SD win I}

New variable to explain, SD difference of psexpectation and actual
winpc. \\

\begin{verbatim}
. gen winsd = ((psexpectation_r - winpc_r)/10)/sdwin;
(474 missing values generated)

. sum winsd;

    Variable |       Obs        Mean    Std. Dev.       Min        Max
-------------+--------------------------------------------------------
       winsd |      3825    5.888271     38.4411  -505.9136   536.5856

. sum winsd if `ifs';

    Variable |       Obs        Mean    Std. Dev.       Min        Max
-------------+--------------------------------------------------------
       winsd |      2523    1.861312     7.69123   -28.5526   29.42124

\end{verbatim}

\end{frame}
